title: Do you agree with this statement: 'It's not a lie if you don't know it's false'? - Quora

response.answer_text: Do you agree with this statement: "It's not a lie if you don't know it's false"? I can rephrase this question to “does ‘lie’ mean that the untruth is deliberate?” And when I have a question about what a word means, I consult a dictionary. Don’t get me wrong: I’m not suggesting that dictionaries always capture all nuances involved with everything. But I am suggesting that if your reaction to what someone else says is “That’s not what that means!” and you consult the dictionary and find that it is, you’re wrong. So let’s check. the definition of lie: a false statement made with deliberate intent to deceive; an intentional untruth; a falsehood. So yes, it seems that this is a common definition. When someone uses a common definition, it’s not a cop-out. It’s how the word is normally used. …claiming something to be true when you don’t actually know it to be true is just as bad as lying. What do you think? I think you’re mistaken. I think that telling lies is immoral. Saying something that you believe is true is not.

To be a lie, it has to have the following characteristics: It’s not true.The person who said it knew it was not true when saying it, and intended to speak an untruth.If you do not know it is false, you can’t honestly call it a lie. Also, if you don’t know the intent of the person who stated it, you also cannot call it a lie. The bar is quite high for calling something a lie, and that is why you do not hear this language often in public discourse. This is why it was so shocking when a Congressman shouted “You lie!” during one of Obama’s State of the Union speeches (also, the rude interruption).

It is more accurate to say that "It is not a lie if you believe that it is true". So, in an unrigged casino, if I say before the roulette wheel is spun "the ball will certainly fall on the number 12", then I am lying, even if the ball does happen to land the number 12. It is a lie because (mental illness aside) I did not believe that the ball would certainly fall on the number 12. Now, believing something to be true is not the same as knowing that something is true, or being free of any doubt that something is true. If I look out the window and at the weather forecast and tell my wife that it won't rain today, then I am not lying if I believe it, even if I know that sometimes forecasts are wrong.

For something to be a lie, there must be intention to deceive or misstate. In the case where the speaker doesn’t actually know that what is being said is false one could still demonstrate intent if the person asserted, without qualification, that he or she was certain that the statement was true. In a case where the person is not absolutely certain that what he or she is saying is true, a qualifier like “I think” or “I believe” or “I’m not absolutely certain” can be used to indicate that there is still some room for doubt. The absence of such a qualifier (when required) may either indicate an intention to mislead (lying), personal negligence (irresponsibility), or an inability to distinguish truth from falsehood or conjecture (mental disorder).

Do you agree with this statement: "It's not a lie if you don't know it's false"? If you make a claim and know it’s false, it’s a lie. If you make a claim and are convinced it to be true but it is not, it’s an error. If you make a claim and are not convinced it to be true, it’s a guess.

No. You repeat a rumor, fact out of context, a CNN queer, Dob Lemon’s voluminous fakery, lies, and slander. You have no idea if it’s the truth or a lie. If it’s a lie, you have just repeated a lie If it’s a truth, you have just repeated a truth. Ignorance does not excuse you from repeating a lie. Or a truth. Careful what you say that you are not certain about.

We have a perfectly good word for that. It is called “mistaken”. Intent matters. Otherwise we’d make no difference between murder and manslaughter. But there is a difference between doing something wrong deliberately, and doing it due to error. If you say something you genuinely believed to be correct, but later turns out not to be, you were mistaken. It is only when you know something is not correct but present it as the truth anyway that you are a liar.

Of course. Lying requires intent. To state something that you believe or assume to be true to as fact, is nothing more than being incorrect, wrong, or giving erroneous information. it is not lying. If you know that the statement is false and make it, that is a lie.

I agree with the OP that it is a cop-out. A lie is a lie, even if the person who spoke it does not know that. A good way to correct someone repeating a lie is to suggest that even if that person thinks it’s true, it is a lie started by (blank) and you should really research this.

Yes. A lie is a deliberate misrepresentation of *what one believes to be* the truth, uttered with the intent to deceive. Accordingly, just as an honest mistake of fact may cause one to utter an untruth without thereby ‘lying’, so it is possible for someone to ‘lie’ while making a factually true statement *if*, at the time, they believed the actual truth to be otherwise and their intent was to mislead.
Disagree. It’s also a lie if you have no real reason to say that it’s true and are attempting to deceive someone into thinking what you know to be speculation is a fact.
